sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• IV dose based on buffer base deficit of extracellular fluid: THAM(R) (mL of 0.3 molar solution) = weight (kg) X base deficit (mEq/L) X 1.1
  • Alkalinization regime - Cardiopulmonary bypass operation: in cardiac bypass surgery, 0.5 to 2.5 g (usual dose is 2 g) added to each 500 mL of ACD blood used for priming the pump-oxygenator
  • Cardiac arrest - Metabolic acidosis: associated with cardiac arrest, if chest is not open, 3.6 to 10.8 g IV; additional amounts may be required to control acidosis that persists after cardiac arrest is reversed; MAX 500 mg/kg/dose
  • Cardiac arrest - Metabolic acidosis: associated with cardiac arrest, if chest is open, 2 to 6 g injected directly into ventricular cavity; do NOT inject into the cardiac muscle
  • Cardiopulmonary bypass operation - Metabolic acidosis: associated with cardiac bypass surgery, 9 mL/kg (324 mg/kg) IV; MAX 500 mg/kg over a period of not less than 1 h

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: geriatric: begin at lower end of dosing range

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Alkalinization regime - Cardiopulmonary bypass operation
  • Cardiac arrest - Metabolic acidosis
  • Cardiopulmonary bypass operation - Metabolic acidosis

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• fluid/solute overloading resulting in dilution of serum electrolyte concentrations, overhydration, congested states, or pulmonary edema may occur
  • hypoglycemia may occur, especially in premature and full term neonates; monitoring recommended
  • large doses; may depress ventilation due to blood pH increase and CO2 decrease; adjust dosage so blood pH is not allowed to increase above normal
  • long-term use; limit use to one day, except in life threatening situations
  • perivascular infiltration leading to inflammation, sloughing of tissue, and necrosis, may occur; use largest vein available and infuse slowly
  • renal disease; increased risk of hypokalemia; monitoring recommended
  • urinary output, reduced; increased risk of hypokalemia; monitoring recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Tromethamine is a fluid replenisher and a parenteral systemic alkalizer that acts as a proton acceptor and binds hydrogen ions actively, thereby preventing or correcting acidosis. It elevates bicarbonate anion concentration by binding to hydrogen ions of carbonic acid. It also exhibits an osmotic diuretic activity which increases urine flow, urinary pH and excretes fixed acids, carbon dioxide and electrolytes.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Intravenous
    • avoid perivascular infiltration because solution is alkaline, infuse slowly and do not exceed a max of 35 g/h
    • (peripheral infusion) indwelling catheter preferred, place in a large vein of an elevated limb
    • (peripheral infusion) if an indwelling catheter is not used, place a large needle in the largest antecubital vein of an elevated limb
    • (cardiac bypass) if chest is closed, give as peripheral infusion
    • (cardiac bypass, ACD blood acidity correction) add 2 g (62 mL) to 500 mL of the ACD blood used to prime the pump-oxygenator
  • Intraventricular
    (cardiac bypass) if chest is open, inject directly into ventricular cavity; do not inject into cardiac muscle

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• blood pH, pCO2, pO2, serum bicarbonate, blood glucose, electrolyte panel; baseline, during and after administration
  • urine output; baseline, during and after administration
  • serum potassium, ECG; in patients with renal disease or reduced urine output
